Award.AwardTitle: Specification of V0v interneurons in the zebrafish spinal cord
Award.AbstractNarration:
To understand how the central nervous system is made and functions, we must first investigate how different nerve cells are made in growing embryos and instructed to connect up into functional circuits. The spinal cord is a powerful system for studying these processes as it is simpler and more experimentally-tractable than the brain. This study will use newly-generated reagents and experimental approaches to identify the key regulatory genes that instruct cells to grow into a particular population of spinal cord nerve cells. These nerve cells are called V0v cells and they are part of the circuitry that regulates locomotion. The project will use genetic and molecular approaches to answer this question. The outcomes of this project will be widely relevant, as this type of nerve cell exists in all vertebrates and the mechanisms and genes identified are likely to play similar roles in other nerve cells. This project will significantly increase our understanding of fundamental biological processes such as how genes instruct cells to grow into particular types of cells and the roles of specific genes in the construction of neuronal circuitry.

The Principal Investigator will incorporate this research into her university teaching and presentations to the general public. This research will also contribute to the diversification of the scientific workforce. Both women and under-represented minorities will actively participate in the project. The Principal Investigator will also continue to perform outreach to local city high schools and to develop teaching modules for both 9th/10th grade and advanced placement high school students. These activities aim to significantly impact the lives of traditionally under-served Syracuse high school students (all of these schools have been identified as Persistently Low Achieving by New York State) and enthuse under represented minority high school students about science and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fundamental question in neuroscience is how different types of neuronal circuits are made in developing embryos. An essential first step in this process is the specification of the distinct nerve cells (neurons) that are needed to form neuronal circuits with appropriate functions. One key property that helps to define different types of neurons is the chemical messenger (called a neurotransmitter) that these cells use to communicate with other cells. Neurons usually use just one of several different neurotransmitters and neurons that utilize inappropriate neurotransmitters form faulty circuits.

 

All of the data so far, suggest that the functional properties of neurons are determined by the regulatory genes that they turn on (express) as these specific cells start to form in the embryo. This project focused on regulatory genes that instruct neurons in the spinal cord to use the neurotransmitter called glutamate. When this project started, we didn’t know any of the regulatory genes that are involved in instructing neurons that are part of locomotor circuitry in the spinal cord to use this neurotransmitter. Therefore, we aimed to identify these genes (genes that specify particular neurons to be glutamatergic (use glutamate as their chemical messenger)). We concentrated on a particular class of glutamatergic neurons that exists in the spinal cords of all vertebrates examined so far and is important for regulating fast movements. In this project, we developed new reagents and experimental approaches, using zebrafish as a model system, that enabled us to identify nine regulatory genes that are strong candidates for specifying glutamatergic phenotypes in this class of neurons and other neurons in the spinal cord. So far, we have shown that six of these genes are indeed required for this process. This project has already resulted in one submitted and three published peer-reviewed papers as well as additional unpublished data and reagents that will be used in future studies.  Several undergraduate researchers, many of them women and under-represented minorities, a graduate student and an under-represented minority postdoctoral fellow have all participated in this research and been trained in experimental, data analysis, scientific logic and communication skills. In addition, reagents and research findings from this project have been essential components of “Bio 305: Integrative Biology lab”, a large sophomore lab class for all Syracuse University Biology and Biochemistry majors (~ 190 students per year).

 

This project also enabled us to continue and build upon our ongoing outreach to local Syracuse City and Solvay School District high schools with the overall aims of significantly impacting the lives of traditionally under-served high school students, enthusing K-12 URM students about science, research and encouraging them to graduate high school and apply to college. All of the Syracuse City School District (SCSD) high schools have student populations with a high percentage of under-represented minorities (URMs) and are designated by New York State as “persistently low achieving”. Approx. 74% of SCSD students are low-income, 56% are African American, 13% Asian, 8% Hispanic and 17% have been diagnosed with a disability. In collaboration with two SCSD high school teachers we have developed and implemented four new hands-on guided-inquiry modules using zebrafish for their classrooms. These teachers teach Living Environment (the New York State Reagents Exam in Biology) and Advanced Placement Biology to approx. 220 students a year. These modules have enabled them to incorporate hands-on experiments into their classrooms to an extent that was not possible before. We have also organized two Biology Apprenticeship days each year for Syracuse City and Solvay School District high school students. These days include tours of the Biology department and zebrafish facility, hands-on experiments with zebrafish addressing questions in genetics and vertebrate development, and an informal discussion with Biology undergraduates, many of whom are under-represented minorities about studying Biology, doing research and applying to college. During this project, we conducted seven of these, reaching 130 students. 57% of these students were young women, 53% were under-represented minorities, three were deaf and one was partially sighted. Finally, we also participated in a two-week summer institute for 9th and 10th graders for three years. We organized a 5-day module where students learnt about vertebrate development and the scientific process by designing their own experiments to test the effects of ethanol on zebrafish embryonic development. Over the three years we reached 49 students, 30 of whom were young women and 39 of whom were under-represented minorities.
